Award.AwardTitle: Repair and Renovation of Faculty Laboratory Facilities at a Comprehensive Public University
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is funded under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (Public Law 111-5).

This award supports a renovation project to provide critical repairs and renovations to a 50-year old laboratory facility utilized by Chemistry and Physics faculty researchers at a comprehensive, public university. The renovation will combine related research areas and specializations into two research centers within the department, one devoted to analytical and forensic chemistry and one devoted to materials research. Laboratory equipment and instrumentation will also be grouped together strategically in the centers so that they are readily available to the faculty and students most likely to use them in their work. Each research center will be assembled during the renovation by the consolidation of smaller research labs and other rooms.

The renovation will also provide safe, sufficient facilities for current faculty research, will improve recruitment of new research faculty, and will provide opportunities to mentor and integrate student trainees in faculty research. The majority of the University's service area includes a rural, economically depressed region of the Mississippi Delta and Missouri 'Bootheel," in which higher than average poverty and unemployment rates, coupled with geographic isolation, limit opportunities for educational attainment and economic stability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to remodel research space for the departments of chemistry and physics as part of the complete renovation of a 1960 era science building, Magill Hall.  Initial construction began in August of 2011.  During the first year of construction, half of the old building was remodeled and a new wing was added to the building.  Only one of the NSF rooms was remodeled in the first year.  During the second year, the other half of the building was remodeled which included the rest of the NSF space.  Fifteen old research rooms were combined into seven newly remodeled and modern research labs.  The new research space became available in August of 2013.  Currently, five of the research labs are being shared by ten faculty members and their students.  Two of the labs are common space including a large instrument room.  Additional pictures of the rooms can be seen by clicking here.

Research areas include green chemistry, organic synthesis, crystallography, water analysis, heavy metal analysis in fish, electrochemistry, biochemistry, food chemistry, biophysical chemistry, spectroscopy, molecular spectroscopy of transition metal complexes, forensic chemistry and chemical education. As a result of research done over the past year, there has been one article accepted for publication and there have been two presentations made at professional meetings.
